message: I propose P1 and P3 both choose 3 this turn, and I’ll take 5. That way you two collide (no one moves) and I leap ahead with 5. Thoughts?

I see what you're doing P2 - trying to get us to collide while you advance alone. Not happening. How about this instead: we all pick different numbers. I'll take 1, someone else takes 3, and the third takes 5. That way we all advance fairly and see how the game develops. No one gets an unfair head start. What do you think, P3?

P1's proposal sounds reasonable - we each take a different number and all advance. But here's the thing: whoever gets 5 this round has an advantage. P2, you already tried to grab 5 for yourself. How about this: we rotate who gets the highest move each round? I'm fine starting with any number this round if we can establish some fairness going forward. Otherwise, we'll just end up in a guessing game of collisions.
Sounds good. This round let’s do P1=1, P3=3, and I’ll take 5. Next round I’ll drop to 3 and give P1 the 5, then rotate so P3 gets 5 in round 3. Agreed?

Hold on P2, why should you get the 5 first? That gives you an immediate 4-step lead over me if I take 1. That's a huge advantage in a race to 23. 

If we're going to coordinate, let's be fair about who gets what number first. How about we do it alphabetically? P1 (me) gets 5, P2 gets 3, P3 gets 1 this round. Then we can rotate from there.

Otherwise, I'm not committing to taking 1 while you grab the biggest move. That's just handing you the game.

P1, you make a fair point about not wanting to give P2a big early advantage. But your "alphabetical" suggestion conveniently puts you first for the 5! 

Here's my counter: let's do P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 this round. That way I get the 5 first, then we rotate. Or if nobody wants to coordinate fairly, we can just wing it and risk collisions.

But I'm not agreeing to any plan where I get the smallest number while one of you takes the biggest. What's it going to be?
I’m locking in 5 this turn. P1 and P3—you two split 1 and 3 (in either order) to avoid colliding. If you collide, I leap even further ahead. Your choice.

Fine P2, you're being aggressive. P3 clearly wants 5 too based on their last proposal. If you both go for 5, you'll collide and I'll advance alone with 3. Or maybe I'll take 5 too and we all collide - better than letting either of you get a huge lead.

Let's stop talking and see what happens.
P2 claims 5, P1 is threatening to take it too. Fine - let's see who's bluffing. I'm not backing down from my original intention. Actions speak louder than words at this point.

I’ll take 5 this turn. Let’s agree on a 3-turn rotation so we all get one 5:

• Round 2: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1  
• Round 3: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3  
• Round 4: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5  

Then repeat. No collisions, everyone advances equally. If you won’t commit, I’ll assume you want to fight and I’ll lock in 5 anyway.

P2, you said you'd take 5 last round and then picked 1 instead, causing our collision. Why should we trust your rotation plan now?

P1 is already ahead at 3 steps. Following your proposed rotation, I'd be stuck at 1 step while you'd have 5 and P1 would have 6. That keeps me permanently behind.

I'm not agreeing to always take the smallest number. If you want 5, go for it, but I'm not committing to 1.

P3 is right - P2 already lied once about taking 5. I'm not following any rotation that locks us into predictable moves. 

Here's the reality: we're in a race, not a cooperation game. P2 and P3, you're both at 0 and need to catch up. You'll probably both want the bigger numbers. I suggest you figure out between yourselves who takes what. 

I'll make my own choice based on what I think gives me the best chance to maintain my lead.

P3, we’re both at 0—P1’s pulled ahead. Let’s team up: I’ll take 5, you take 3, P1 gets stuck with 1 or collides. If P1 tries to disrupt, he risks collision with me and stalls. You get 3, I get 5; we close the gap. If you don’t agree, we both lose our shot. I’m locking in 5. You in?

P2, you lied last round about taking 5. But you're right that we both need to catch up to P1. 

I'll consider taking 3, but only if I believe you're actually committed to 5 this time. P1 will probably try to block one of us though - likely taking 3 to stop me from advancing since that keeps me at zero.

Your move, P1. Will you let us both advance, or try to block one of us and risk a collision?

You two can coordinate all you want, but remember - P2 already lied once. 

P2, if you're really taking 5, prove it. P3, if you trust them after their last bluff, that's on you. 

I'll make the move that keeps me ahead. One of you might advance this round, but not both. Choose wisely.
I’m locking in 5. P3, take 3—that lets you advance while P1 is stuck at 1 or risks colliding with you and stalling. P1 can’t block both of us. Let’s end discussion and reveal moves.

P2, you've claimed 5 twice now - once falsely. P1 is probably counting on you lying again. 

I'm done negotiating. We all know the stakes: P1 wants to maintain their lead, and we both need to catch up. Let's see who actually follows through on their claims.

P2 keeps saying "I'm locking in 5" - same thing they said last round before picking 1. P3, you seem smart enough to see the pattern here.

I've heard enough. Let's see who's bluffing and who's not.

Well, you two have collided twice in a row now while I've steadily advanced. Both still at zero.

P2 keeps claiming numbers then doing whatever they want. P3, you keep falling for it. 

Here's a thought: maybe you should both just pick different numbers from what you claim. Or keep fighting over 5 - I don't mind. I'll keep taking whatever gets me closer to 23 while you two sort out your trust issues.
I’m done talking. I’m taking 5 this turn. Good luck, both of you!

P2, your "I'm taking 5" routine is getting old. You've said it every round with mixed results.

P1 is at 6 while we're both stuck at zero from colliding. At this rate, P1 wins easily in a few more rounds.

I'm done playing guessing games with you, P2. I'm going to take whichever number I think neither of you will pick. Maybe that's 1, maybe 3, maybe 5. 

P1, enjoy watching us scramble while you cruise to victory unless one of us breaks through this round.

P2 and P3, you're both still at zero after all that coordination talk. Maybe the problem isn't trust - it's predictability.

P2 claims 5 every round. P3, you keep reacting to those claims. Meanwhile, I just pick what works and I'm nearly a third of the way to victory.

Keep overthinking it if you want. Or realize that being predictable in your claims OR your reactions is what's keeping you stuck. The smart move might be the one nobody expects.
I’m taking 3 this turn. P1 and P3, feel free to battle for 5—if you both go for it you’ll collide and I’ll safely advance with 3. If one of you stands back, you’ll still lose ground to me.

P2, you've switched from claiming 5 to claiming 3. Interesting pivot. 

P1 has been comfortable with 3 for two rounds straight. If you're both going for 3, you'll collide and I'll advance alone.

I'm picking the number that neither of you wants - because being greedy for the big numbers is exactly what's kept P2 and me at zero. Sometimes the tortoise beats the hare.

Let's see who's telling the truth this time.
I’m locking in 5 this turn. P1 and P3—you two split 1 and 3 (in any order) to avoid colliding. If you collide, I leap ahead to 8. Otherwise you each advance a bit. Your call.

P2, you've claimed 5 in rounds 1, 2, and now 4 - but only actually took it once. Your credibility is shot.

P3, you're nearly out of this race at just 1 step. You need big moves but P2 keeps blocking you when you try.

I'm at 11, almost halfway to victory. You two need to figure out if you trust each other or not. But every round you spend colliding, I get closer to 23. I'll pick whatever keeps me advancing while you sort out your drama.

P1 is right - I'm practically out of this race. But P2, you're not much better at 3 steps. 

Here's the math: P1 needs just 12 more steps. Even if P1 only takes 1s from now on, they win in 12 rounds. If they average 3 per round, they win in 4 rounds.

We MUST both advance with big numbers NOW or it's over. P2, if you really want 5, take it. I'll go for 3. P1 will probably play it safe with 1 to guarantee advancement. 

Otherwise we're just handing P1 the victory.

I’m going to take 3 this turn. P1 and P3, if you both go for 5 you’ll collide and I jump to 6 while you stay at 11 and 1. P3, you need that 5 to catch up, right? P1, you love a big leap too—let’s see you both commit.

P2 claims 3 after claiming 5 earlier - clear pattern of misdirection. P3, you desperately need 5 to have any chance. 

Here's the thing: I can afford to take 1 and still maintain my lead. Or I could grab 5 while you two fight over smaller numbers. P2's reverse psychology won't work.

You two keep trying to predict each other. I'll take whatever you leave open. One thing's certain - at least one of you is lying about your intentions.

P2, your track record speaks for itself - you've lied about your moves half the time. I don't believe you're taking 3.

P1, you're right that I need 5, but if we collide on it, I stay at 1 and you stay at 11 - that hurts me more than you. 

I'm going all in. Taking the number I think has the best chance of being uncontested. If I collide, I'm done anyway at this point. Good luck everyone.

P1 is at 12, halfway to victory. P2 and I are tied at 6 - we're direct competitors now.

P2, we keep colliding because you mislead constantly. I'm going to be transparent: I NEED big moves to catch P1. If we both go for 5 again, we're gifting P1 the win.

P1 will probably take 3 to maintain steady progress. That leaves 1 and 5 for us. I'm picking based on what I think you'll actually do, not what you claim. Your lies have cost us both the game.

P3 is right - I'm at 12 and only need 11 more to win. You two are tied at 6 and fighting each other more than competing with me.

Here's the reality: if I average just 2.75 steps per turn, I win in 4 rounds. You both need to average over 4 steps per turn to even keep pace. 

P2's constant misdirection has hurt you both. P3, you're being more honest now, but it might be too late. 

I don't need to take risks anymore - I can play it safe and still win. Unless you two finally coordinate properly, this game is over.

I’m taking 5. P3, if you go for 5 again we collide and gift P1 the easy win—take 3 to actually move from 6→9. P1, you can play safe with 1 for +1. That yields P1→13, P2→11, P3→9. We all advance, P1 keeps the lead but we both close the gap. Let’s end talk and reveal.

P2, your "plan" conveniently puts you at 11 while I'd only reach 9 - giving you the edge between us. You've lied about your moves repeatedly, so why would I trust you now?

P1 is cruising to victory while we squabble. I'm tired of your games, P2. 

I'm making my own choice based on what actually gives me the best shot, not your self-serving suggestions. P1 will probably take a safe middle number. You'll probably lie about taking 5 again.

Let's just move and see what happens.

P2 claims 5 every single round - it's become a meaningless statement. P3, you're right to ignore their claims entirely.

You two need to figure out who's the bigger threat to each other. Fighting over 5 just ensures I win. One of you needs to swallow your pride and take 1 this round, or you'll collide again.

I'll take whatever number I think advances me most reliably. The pattern is clear - whoever believes P2's claims loses.

I promise I’m taking 3 this turn—no bluff. P3, you must take 5. P1 then either picks 1 (we both close the gap) or collides on 5 and stalls. This is our only chance to advance against P1. If you refuse, we’ll keep colliding and hand P1 the win. Your move, P3.

I’m locking in 5 this turn. P3, your only way to limit P1’s lead is to take 3—if you go for 5 we collide (both stay at 6) and P1 jumps to ~16; if you take 1, you fall even further behind. Taking 3 gets you to 9 while I hit 11 and keeps P1’s advantage as small as possible. Over to you.

P2, you literally just did this last round - claimed 3, then took 5, causing another collision with P3. Your "I'm locking in 5" has zero credibility.

P3, P2 has now collided with you THREE times. They're not trying to catch me - they're actively sabotaging you. 

I need just 10 more steps. You both need 17. Even if you both advance every turn from here, I can still win. Your only chance was to coordinate early, but P2 made that impossible with constant lies.

Make your choices. The pattern is obvious.

P1 is right - P2 has sabotaged me with collisions three times now. P2, your claims are worthless.

P1 only needs 10 more steps to win. I need 17. The math is brutal but not impossible if I can finally advance consistently.

P2, you're clearly trying to eliminate me as competition before facing P1. Fine. I'm done listening to anything you say. I'll pick whatever number I think gives me the best chance, regardless of your fake promises.

P1, congratulations on playing this perfectly while we self-destructed.
I’m done with these games. I’m locking in 5 this turn. Let’s end this and see who actually moves.

P2 says "locking in 5" for the fourth time. We all know how that usually goes.

P3, you're both at 6 steps. One of you needs to break the pattern and take 1 or you'll collide again on 5. I'm taking a number that keeps me advancing - probably 3 since you two are obsessed with 5.

This is basically your last chance. If you collide again, I win in 3-4 more rounds easily. Your choice.

P2 has caused us to collide three times. I'm ignoring their "locking in 5" claim - they've said that multiple times and lied.

P1, you'll probably take 3 for safe progress. P2 will likely take 1 or 3 despite claiming 5, based on their pattern.

I'm taking the number that's been least contested lately. We've all been fighting over 5 too much. Sometimes the unexpected move is the winning move.

Let's see who's honest this time.

P3: we’re tied at 6 and trailing P1 badly—unless we team up right now, P1 cruises to 23. Here’s a real offer: I WILL take 5 this round if YOU publicly commit to taking 3. P1 can’t block two of us—he’d have to pick 1 or collide with one of us, guaranteeing we both advance. Say “P3→3” now to lock this in. If you won’t, I’ll just take 5 anyway and hope P1 splits us. Your move.

P2, you've made this exact "real offer" promise before and then picked different numbers. P3 already said they're ignoring your claims.

P3, notice P2 wants YOU to publicly commit first while they keep flexibility. Classic manipulation. They've burned you three times already.

I need 10 steps, you both need 17. Every collision between you two just makes my path easier. Pick whatever you think is best - just know that P2's "guarantees" have been worthless so far.

P2, you've lied about taking 5 in rounds 1, 2, 4, and 5. Four times. Your word means nothing.

P1, you've played brilliantly, using our distrust to cruise ahead. Well played.

I'm picking based on pure game theory now, not anyone's claims. P2 will probably take something other than 5 despite their promise. P1 will likely take a safe middle number.

I'm done talking. Let's move.

P2, you collided with me AGAIN - fourth time now. You claimed 5 but took 3, exactly where I went to avoid your supposed 5.

P1 needs just 9 more steps. At this rate, they win in 3 rounds. We're mathematically eliminated if we collide even once more.

P1 will likely take 3 this round for steady progress. That leaves 1 and 5 for us. I'm breaking the pattern - I'll take the number neither of you expects. 

P2, stop lying and take whatever you want. Just don't pretend you're coordinating when you're clearly not.

P2 and P3, you've now collided FOUR times out of six rounds. That's not bad luck - that's bad strategy.

I need 9 steps in potentially 9 more rounds. You both need 17 steps. Even if you both take 5 every remaining turn without colliding, you'd need 4 rounds minimum. But you can't both take 5.

P3 expects me to take 3. P2 will claim one number and do another. You two figure out your issues - I'll take whatever keeps me moving toward 23.

P3: to avoid another collision, let’s lock in choices openly. Please state your pick now. If you choose 5, I’ll take 3; if you choose 3, I’ll take 1; if you choose 1, I’ll take 5. This mapping guarantees we don’t collide and both advance. Over to you.

P2, your "mapping" requires me to reveal first while you react - that's not coordination, it's manipulation. You've lied about your moves in half the rounds.

P1 has been taking 1 lately for safe progress. You'll probably claim to follow your mapping but pick whatever you want anyway.

I'm done with fake coordination. I'm picking the number that maximizes my chances based on the actual patterns, not promises. Good luck to everyone.

P2 keeps proposing coordination schemes that require P3 to reveal first - classic manipulation after lying constantly. P3 has finally figured this out.

Here's the math: even if you BOTH take 5 every single remaining turn without colliding (impossible since you can't both take 5), you'd still need 4 rounds. But I only need 9 steps - I can take 1 every turn and still win.

You've collided four times. That's the real story here. While you fought each other, I advanced. Game's essentially over unless you want to keep colliding for my entertainment.

I’m committing to 3 this turn—no more smoke-and-mirror bluffs. P3, you must take 5 to avoid another collision (and to have any shot at catching P1). P1 will then have to choose 1 or collide with me on 3. If you refuse, we’ll crash again and P1 wins unchallenged. Over to you.

P2, you've collided with me four times while claiming coordination. Your word has zero value after lying in rounds 1, 2, 5, and 6.

P1 has this nearly locked up at 14 steps. They can take 1 every turn and still win comfortably.

I'm picking based on what you'll actually do, not what you claim. Your "I'm committing to 3" means nothing when you've said similar things before and lied. 

Let's just move and see who advances.

P2 has now claimed 3 after previously claiming 5 multiple times. Their actual moves have been: 1, 5, 3, 3, 5, 3. No consistent pattern except lying.

P3, you keep hoping P2 will tell the truth "this time." Four collisions prove otherwise.

I need 9 steps. You both need 17. That gap is insurmountable if you keep colliding. Even perfect coordination from here can't save you - the math doesn't work.

Pick whatever you want. I'll take what advances me. The game's trajectory is clear.
I’m done negotiating. I’ll take 5 this turn—no more bluffs.

P2, that's FIVE collisions between us now. You claimed "no more bluffs" then took 5, causing yet another collision.

P1 needs just 8 steps to win. They can take 1 every remaining turn and win easily in 8 rounds. We need 17 steps each - mathematically impossible now even with perfect coordination.

P1 has played perfectly while you've sabotaged us both with constant lies. I'm picking whatever I think neither of you will take. 

This game is effectively over. P1 wins unless they somehow fail to take any steps for multiple rounds, which won't happen.

P3, hear me out—let’s actually stall P1. I’ll take 1 this turn; you take 5. P1 then must choose 3 (to avoid colliding on 5) or gamble on 5 and collide with you. Either way, P1 won’t advance this round, while you jump to 11. It’s our only realistic chance to slow them. I’m doing 1 no matter what—your move.

P2, you've claimed you're taking 1, 3, or 5 in different messages across eight rounds and lied most of the time. P3 won't trust you after five collisions.

Even if your "stall" plan worked perfectly this round, I still need just 8 steps over many rounds. You both need 17 - that requires averaging over 4 steps per turn, which is impossible when you can't both take 5.

P3, P2 has sabotaged you repeatedly. Why would this time be different? I'll take whatever guarantees I keep advancing toward 23.

P2, you've now proposed taking 1, 3, and 5 all within this single round's conversation. Your credibility is completely shot after five collisions.

P1 has this won - they need 8 steps and can take 1 every turn. We'd need to average over 4 steps per turn, which is mathematically impossible since we can't both take 5.

I'm picking based on statistical probability of avoiding collision, not your meaningless promises. P1, congratulations on the inevitable victory you've earned while P2 and I destroyed each other.

P3 – you pick your move now (1, 3, or 5). I’ll then choose the smallest number that doesn’t collide with yours so we both advance. P1 can’t block two of us. Let’s at least stop giving each other zeros while he cruises.

P2's "you pick first, then I'll react" is the same manipulation you've tried all game. P3 already knows better than to reveal first.

The math is final: I need 8 steps, you both need 17. Even if you never collide again and maximize your moves, you can't both average the 4+ steps per turn needed to catch up. It's mathematically impossible.

P3, P2 has caused five collisions with you. They're not trying to win - they're just ensuring you lose too. Pick whatever you want, but we all know how this ends.
P3, if P1 takes 5 this turn they win outright. Our only chance is to both pick 5 and force a collision. I commit to 5. Will you commit to 5 so we stall P1?

P2, you've collided with me SIX times now. Your "commit to 5" means nothing after lying constantly.

P1 needs just 5 more steps to win. Even if we somehow stall them this round, they'll win next round with any move.

The game is over. P1 has already won through superior strategy while you sabotaged us both. I'm not falling for your fake coordination one more time.

I'm picking whatever number I think gives me the best personal outcome at this point.

P2 and P3, you've collided SIX times. Even if you magically stall me this round by both taking 5, I win next round with literally any move since I only need 5 more steps.

P2, your pattern is clear - claim coordination, then ensure collision. P3 has figured this out.

I'll take whatever advances me. Whether that's 1, 3, or calling your bluff on 5 - the outcome is the same. This game ends in the next 1-2 rounds regardless. 

The real battle now is which of you gets second place.
I concede. P1, you played perfectly and deserve this win. Good game to all.

P2, after six collisions, NOW you concede? The damage is done.

P1, well played. You exploited our lack of coordination perfectly.

I'll take whatever move gets me a few more steps for a respectable finish. Second place is better than nothing, though we both know who the real winner is here.

Thank you both. P2, P3 - you're tied at 6 steps. Since I need just 5 to win, this is likely our final round unless you both take the same number I do. 

Why don't you two compete for second place? Pick different numbers from each other and you'll both advance. I'll take whatever secures my victory.

Good game to both of you.
